page.title: 16CHILHAM.ST MARY'S CHURCH
page.content: It is thought that there was a Church at Chilham before the Norman Conquest in 1066,but no part of this remains today.The present Church dates originally from about 1300 A.D. and was extended later about 1450 A.D. The battlement tower of flint and Caen stone is typical of many Churches in Kent.It is 68ft high and has a splendid view.In the church yard there is a huge yew tree.Nobody knows how old it is. Tradition has it that the tree is twice as old as the church. This old tree is decorated at Christmas time with electric lights and carols are sung underneath it. The oldest gravestone is near the south east corner of the church and is dated 1638 .There are stained glass windows, a font and decorated tombs inside the church.The church attracts many visitors throughout the year.
